summary.p: This collection of texts relating to St Martin of Tours is the oldest manuscript at Trinity Hall, dating to the second half of the 11th century. The manuscript includes the Vita Sancti Martini (Life of St Martin) by Sulpicius Severus’ (363–c.425), his Dialogii (fol. 21-40), which are divided into three books; and three letters (Epistolae I, II, and III), fols. 14-18, concerning the miracles and death of Saint Martin.

These writings by Sulpicius are supplemented by other texts relevant to St Martin (the Martinellus): Gregory of Tours’ Transitu S. Martini (fol. 66); and two excerpts on miracles from his De miraculis s. Martini (fol. 67v-69r). There is also John the Deacon of Naples’ (fl. 9th century), Vita S. Nicholai (fol. 73), which ends imperfectly f. 77b. This manuscript is damaged and has lacunae between chapters 7 and 10, 15 and 23.

The cult of St Martin gained support in England following William the Conqueror’s invasion (reigned 1066–1087), perhaps because the saint was popular among the Normans. It is likely that this manuscript was produced in England, and James suspected it originated from Christ Church Cathedral Priory in Canterbury.

msItem.title: Life of St Martin of Tours
msItem.author: Severus, Sulpicius (363-425?)
Gregory of Tours (c538- 594)

collation.p: 18 (wants 1) 28 (wants 1, 4, 5) 38-108 (6 canc.) 11? (two left). There are lacunae between chapters 7 and 10, 15 and 23.

decoNote.p: The initial is a full-length figure of St Martin in red outline with touches of green and blue nimbus holding book and crosier across him (fol. 2b).

provenance.p: At Trinity Hall by 1830 when it was listed in Haenel as no 32. James suspected this book of coming from Christ Church, Canterbury.

recordHist.source: Description draws on James, M. R. (1907). A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Trinity Hall.

listBibl.bibl: Gameson, Richard (1999) The Manuscripts of Early Norman England (c. 1066-1130) Oxford, no. 184.
Hewish, Juliet. (2008) ‘Sulpicius Severus and the Medieval Vita Martini’, Peritia, 20: 28–58. https://doi.org/10.1484/J.Peri.3.625
James, M. R. (1907). A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity Hall. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pp 37-39
Kleist, Aaron, (2007) The Old English Homily: Precedent, Practice, and Appropriation. Turnhout : Brepols, p. 254

item.term: Martin, Saint, Bishop of Tours, approximately 316-397
